posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Before starting, figured I’d ask. We want to make a comprehensive list of wire stripping lengths for common FRC components (Wago 221, PDH , PDP , VRM , PCM , etc), so that we don’t have to look them up repeatedly or strip them incorrectly. I can’t find one searching here but I seem to struggle with the search feature a lot. Thanks.

Our electrical manual has many of these in their respective crimping sections

This Doc is private

These also have guides on how to do the crimps or connectors.

As for the lengths, I just realized the 221 isn’t in there, but here are some Wago 221: 0.43 inches Wago 2601: 0.33 inches (the small power and CAN connectors on the newer PDH ) Wago 2616: 0.75 inches ( PDH battery) Wago 2606: 0.5 inches ( PDH main power out) WCP Inline CAN : 0.375 inches Molex SL: 0.125 inches Anderson PP 15/30/45: 5/16th inches (we used around 0.25 instead, but oh well) Anderson SB50: 0.5 inches Ring terminals: 1 inch (Ours may be different so you will have to check this, this is for our battery rings) Weidmullers: 0.375 inches (these are the little push pins on the Rio, VRM , CAN stuff sometimes, PDP 1, power for PCM , etc) CTRE PDP Wago: 0.375 inches

Most of these dimensions are either best guesses based on our hardware, or come from the manufacturers. If anyone notices any errors, please post them, but I believe these to be accurate

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked:
FinIce:

As for the lengths, I just realized the 221 isn’t in there, but here are some Wago 221: 0.43 inches

What…. It’s alright we all make mistakes lol

Wonderful resource though definitely be showing this to a few people thankyou

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Another important dimension is the minimum distance to the tie-down to let the terminals float so they align well upon insertion and aren’t continuously stressed.

An example from the Molex SL specification PS-73838-005-001.pdf

image 1096×855 130 KB

image 1096×855 130 KB

image 1096×855 130 KB

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: This is great, thank you. How precisely do you measure strip distances? I know these are optimal, but is it better to be a wee bit long than short?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Many components also have the stripping length marked on the thing itself. Wagos definitely do for example.

FredK:

How precisely do you measure strip distances?

Eyeballing it for the most part. Sometimes I will check the stripped length against the connector and see if it will make sense with how the connector is properly crimped, then adjust from there. As you crimp more your judgements on lengths and stuff will improve.

Personally whether it is longer or shorter depends on the wire I am doing. For the most part I prefer longer strip lengths because I can trim the wire instead of trying to strip a very small bit of insulation. For battery wire I do prefer shorter because the insulation is easier to trim off.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
FinIce:

Ring terminals: 1 inch

This must be a huge ring terminal to have a strip length of 1 inch

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
FinIce:

Molex SL: 0.125 inches

Might be worth noting that the official spec is .100-.125, so you’re better off aiming a little under. 3mm is right in the sweet spot, and our knipex wire stripper has an adjustable stop that can do 6mm, so I tell our students to strip to 6mm, then cut the stripped length in half to get a feel for how long it’s supposed to be
Its a 4awg for our batteries. I did note that it varied a lot, should have specified it was for our batteries though.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
As an alternative, I made a few “strip gauges” that are designed to be zip tied to a lanyard (mostly just to make them longer and harder to lose).

Check out Onshape

image 1144×1069 132 KB

image 1144×1069 132 KB

image 1144×1069 132 KB

There are Molex SL and APP gauges (the Molex are a little longer than Molex spec but seem to work better when crimping using a non-Molex SL manual crimper - Engineer PA-09 is my favorite crimper in the world).

The gauges include a go/no-go (indicating within the range and not too short or too long).  We encourage people to strip a little long and use the “Trim” positions of the gauge to trim the conductor for the smaller wires with a utility knife of a bigger X-acto style knife.

In general, it’s worked pretty well and has been reasonably consistent for folks to use with a quick explanation.

We 3D print them and when they get chewed up, we just toss them and print another.

One 3D printing tip, print them “on their back” (that is with the “Too long”, “Too short”, and “Trim” text on the top); that way you can get very accurate dimensions to the measurement protrusion because if you print them “standing up”, layer heights can come into play and doing it on their backs puts all that in the X-Y plane which is typically more closely maintained for most slicers.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
The users manuals for the PDH , PDP , VRM , PCM , etc. all contain the information you are looking for.

I typically send my students to the users manuals first for such information because they should be more authoritative than a random post somewhere on the internet.
